awd_titl_txt: SCC-PG - Connecting Communities through Smart Tools and Sensors to Deliver Enhanced Ecosystem Services and Economic Returns from Regenerative Farmland Management
awd_abstract_narration:
The way that we manage our agricultural lands is at the nexus of two of the greatest challenges facing humanity: 1) reversing land and soil degradation while maintaining sustainable production of food and fiber to meet growing global demands, and 2) harnessing the potential of soil carbon sequestration for drawdown of atmospheric CO2 to help stabilize global climate. To accomplish these goals will require fundamental changes in agricultural land management and the broader structure of our food systems. Central to this restructuring must be an emphasis on improving soil health and managing agricultural systems to provide environmental ecosystem services (e.g., carbon sequestration, improved water quality, reduced erosion, biodiverse pollinator habitat, etc.) as important coproducts to crop yields. Supporting the transition to, and maintenance of, this so-called regenerative farmland management requires monetizing the value of the various environmental services provided and ensuring that farmers retain a greater proportion of the value of both the crops and environmental services they cultivate. Our proposal seeks to develop a greater understanding of the opportunities for and barriers to adoption of regenerative agricultural practices, as well as collective decision-making about land use management by regional farming communities. 

To carry out this investigation, this project will bring together the nation’s leading soil scientists and social scientists with Pecan Street’s award-winning engineering team to design an integrative research project laying the technological and social foundations for facilitating regenerative farmland management. This project will 1) enhance and expand an existing farm greenhouse gas (GHG) accounting system (COMET-Farm) with state-of-the-art sensors and geospatial datasets to better facilitate landscape-scale assessments for rural communities, and 2) pilot that system in select communities with a goal of nudging farmers off individual-level decision-making towards collective decisions about regenerative farmland management that will result in improved, marketable carbon sequestration and ecosystem service provisioning.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Through its ?SCC-PG - Connecting Communities through Smart Tools and Sensors to Deliver Enhanced Ecosystem Services and Economic Returns from Regenerative Farmland Management? project, researchers from Pecan Street, Cornell University, and Texas State University sought to conduct the background research, partnership development, and planning needed to develop a proposal for a full research project aimed at facilitating regenerative farmland management through community-scale decision-making. A literature review [https://www.pecanstreet.org/publications/regenaglit/] revealed the potential of different social science approaches for building individual and collective knowledge that could support the adoption of regenerative practices and technologies in the agricultural sector. Surveys [https://www.pecanstreet.org/farmersurvey/] and focus groups helped illuminate farmer demographics, products, income, and other factors currently shaping decisions around agricultural land management in target communities in New York and Texas. A technology review helped to clarify the geographic limitations, accuracy of carbon predictions, effort needed to gather data, effort to integrate and report results, farmer friendliness for solutions such as near infrared (NIR) and mid infrared (MIR) sensors that take proxy measurements of soil carbon, computer models that estimate changes in soil carbon resulting from land management practices, and platforms that support collection, sharing, and interpretation of on-farm observations. An interdisciplinary team from Pecan Street, Cornell University, Texas State University, the Woodwell Climate Research Center, and Hudson Carbon came together to support the development of a proposal for the 2022 Smart and Connected Communities solicitation.

Key learnings from this planning grant effort included:  

  • In the near-term, soil carbon measurement and verification innovation may come from data analytics rather than soil sensor technology. NIR and MIR sensors have emerged in the marketplace, but they are relatively expensive, require local calibration with a spectroscopic library, and are likely infeasible for use by many small to mid-sized producers.

  • Additional research and data collection are also needed to ensure the accuracy and usability of model-based approached to soil carbon measurement and verification. Most models are complex and beyond what most farmers can calibrate and run independently. Equally important, most models primarily support commodity crops, leaving a significant gap for small- and mid-sized producers who grow our food crops.
  • While a risk-innovation review was inconclusive with respect to determining which variables most influence a farmer / rancher?s likelihood of adopting a new technology or management practice change (i.e., size of operation, geographic region, and farmer sociodemographic characteristic), it is clear that designing outreach for any solution specifically for a local audience is important.

  • Farmers? sense of identity and agency is critical to decision-making. Although producers may choose to experiment with a practice that solves a particular problem on their farm, regenerative agriculture is often perceived more as a social movement than a specific land management practice or suite of practices. Equally, farmers interested in regenerative agricultural practices often do not find support in their local community of place and seek out information and support online from more distributed communities of practice. These online information resources may not be tailored to regional conditions and could result in inappropriate practice recommendations for farmers in different regions. Farmers new to regenerative agriculture may not find sufficient social reinforcement to counter-balance relationships, norms, culture, and broader forces in the local community. Local knowledge-sharing of best practices for regional conditions and soil type as well as social reinforcement are critical to supporting farmers through the multi-year transition process that is necessary to accrue the economic and the ecosystem and climate benefits of regenerative agriculture practices. Techno-social interventions should support farmers to collect, make meaning of, and share observational data on their farms so that they can internalize changes happening as a result of their efforts and can compare experiences with their peers.
  • Classic diffusion of innovation approaches may have unintended consequences within agricultural communities. Investing resources in educating early adopter farmers on new innovations and supporting adoption can perpetuate a cycle of inequity in production and wealth accumulation. Instead, education and farm trial approaches that work with groups of farmers together could be far more effective at accelerating a transition to regenerative and climate-smart farming practices.
